subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
Unorthodox variant {{Han simp|噓|f=虛|t=虚|nocap=y}}. Found in the {{w|Jiyun}} 《{{w2|zh|集韻}}》 dictionary published during the {{w|Song dynasty}} (1039 AD).

Eventually adopted as an official form by the {{w|People's Republic of China}} in 1965 based on the Table of General Used Chinese Characters for Publishing 《{{w2|zh|印刷通用漢字字形表}}》 where {{w|Xin Zixing}} ({{w2|zh|新字形#新舊字形對照表|新字形}}) is promulgated for the first time.

subSections.title: Readings
Etymology
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|うそ}}
Attested in the late {{w|Heian period}}. Possibly cognate with {{m|ja|嘯く|tr=usobuku||to [[boast]]}}.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: * In Japanese, using ''uso'' is less inflammatory than calling something a lie in English; it is used similar to "No way!" or "Really!"
